description: From Latin allūs-, past participle stem of allūdere (“to joke, jest”; see allude) +‎ -ive.

adjectives.description: allusive (comparative more allusive, superlative most allusive)

entries.meaning: that contains or makes use of allusions (indirect references or hints)
examples: English poetry is compelled by the stubbornness of the language continually to renounce the too obviously poetic: but in seeking to be more precise, more dense and more allusive, Russian poetry has never had to give up the straightforward traditional intoxications of sound and rhyme.
